reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-001 (library: System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition)
reinforcements.similarity: Both identify trust verification as a critical gate at phase transitions, particularly for professional hosts. New element focuses specifically on authority credential verification (licenses, known partners, track record) at discovery/evaluation phases. Existing element establishes broader System 1 trust principle across all phase transitions.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: 'System 1 immediately asks: Am I safe here? Can I trust this?' at every phase transition. New (Jessica): 'Jessica spent first 3 minutes interrogating legitimacy (Do you work with management companies?)' — this is System 1 defensive mode triggered by insufficient authority signals at discovery phase. Combined evidence strengthens the principle that trust gates require immediate, visible credibility markers (not just general safety reassurance).
reinforcements.recommendation: merge — New element provides concrete specification of what 'trust signals' mean in discovery/evaluation phases (authority credentials: licenses, partner logos, testimonials). Merge into existing works-001 as a detailed implementation pattern for professional host segment.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address economic transparency and reducing cognitive load during financial evaluation. Existing element focuses on showing one total before breakdown. New element (Transparent Economics Before Commitment) focuses on providing ROI calculator + conversion benchmarks before commitment.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: 'Show one number first. The host needs an anchor... Then break it down.' New (Jessica): 'Jessica spent 6+ minutes negotiating pricing because economics were unclear. ROI calculator would externalize mental math.' Both recognize that hosts need clear, immediate financial understanding to commit. Existing focuses on presentation hierarchy (one number first), new focuses on interactive tools (calculator) and comparative data (vs. traditional broker fee).
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both — These are complementary, not duplicate. Existing element is about display hierarchy (show total before breakdown). New element is about providing interactive economic modeling tools and comparative benchmarks. Both serve economic clarity but at different layers.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: feels-001 (library: Cognitive Ease as Foundation of Trust)
reinforcements.similarity: Both use Cialdini's 'arguing against own interests' principle to build trust. New element focuses on Robert's honest constraint feedback ('pricing things out of market'). Existing element focuses on cognitive ease in first 2 seconds.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: 'The first 2 seconds set everything. If the host's System 1 detects friction, cognitive alarm bells ring.' New (Jessica): 'Robert built trust by saying lower-cost inventory is better, arguing against Split Lease short-term interests.' Both recognize that trust is built through honest, friction-reducing design. Existing focuses on reducing cognitive friction (ease). New focuses on reducing motivational suspicion (honesty).
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both — Different trust mechanisms. Existing = cognitive ease (make it effortless). New = honest guidance (make it trustworthy through transparent constraints). Both are trust-building but distinct psychological principles.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address scarcity/demand validation through proof rather than claims. Existing element focuses on showing guaranteed income to create relief. New element (Scarcity Validation Through Early Proof) focuses on validating demand claims within first week through waitlist snapshot + engagement metrics.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: 'Relief of guaranteed income: Show the money, then show why it's safe.' New (Jessica): 'If test listings don't receive proposals quickly, Jessica will conclude demand was oversold. Scarcity must be newly experienced (Cialdini), not just asserted.' Both recognize that hosts need proof, not promises. Existing focuses on income guarantee proof, new focuses on demand proof.
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both — Different proof types serving different anxieties. Existing = income security proof. New = demand reality proof. Both are evidence-based trust building but address different host concerns.

reinforcements.similarity: Both establish authority credentials as primary information layer. Existing: 'Process Before Promise, Verification Before Claim.' New: 'Authority Credential Stack: Front-Load Legitimacy Signals' with specific hierarchy: licenses, known partners, testimonials.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: 'Show proof of process before making promises. Lead with mechanism, not outcome.' New (Jessica): 'Front-load authority credentials so hosts verify legitimacy before engaging with business model. Primary layer (first 3 seconds): Licensed platform badge, property count, social proof.' Both prioritize credibility establishment before value proposition. Existing is broader principle (proof before promise), new is specific implementation (exactly which credentials, in what order).
reinforcements.recommendation: merge — New element provides detailed specification of what 'trust credential stack' means for professional hosts at discovery. Merge as implementation detail of existing communicates-003.

reinforcements.similarity: Both define typography system for trust-building. Existing: 'Serif for Recognition, Sans for Action, Mono for Verification.' New: 'Economic Transparency Dashboard uses mono for financial figures (precision/trust), serif for headlines (authority), sans for labels (clarity).'
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: 'Mono signals precision and reliability. Use for prices, stats, badges.' New (Jessica): 'Use IBM Plex Mono 28px bold for key financial figures to signal precision/trust. ROI calculator leverages mono typography for all dollar amounts.' Both use same typographic trust principle: mono = precision = trust for financial/data elements. New element is specific application of existing principle to ROI calculator.
reinforcements.recommendation: merge — New element is implementation example of existing typographic trust principle. Demonstrates principle in action for economic transparency tools.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: behaves-001 (library: Instant Acknowledgment on Every Host Input)
reinforcements.similarity: Both establish real-time feedback as core interaction principle. Existing: 'Sub-100ms acknowledgment on every input.' New: 'Economic Calculator Real-Time Feedback Loop with 300ms debounce, instant visual acknowledgment, value count-up animations.'
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: 'The platform must acknowledge every host action within 100ms. Cursor blinks, field highlights, something moves.' New (Jessica): 'Calculator updates in real-time—no submit button, no delay. Use 300ms debouncing but display loading shimmer immediately.' Both prioritize instant feedback. Existing is general principle (acknowledge all inputs), new is specific implementation for calculator (debounce logic + shimmer during wait).
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both — Existing is platform-wide interaction principle. New is specific application to calculator with additional complexity (debouncing, animations). Keep both: existing as principle, new as detailed calculator implementation.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: feels-001 (library: Cognitive Ease as Foundation of Trust)
reinforcements.similarity: Both identify trust-building as primary emotional journey. Existing focuses on cognitive ease (reduce friction). New (Professional Skepticism to Collaborative Trust) focuses on authority demonstration + honest guidance.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing: 'First 2 seconds set everything. If System 1 detects friction, cognitive alarm bells ring. Design must feel effortless.' New (Jessica): 'Jessica opened defensive (skeptical) and ended warm (trusting) because Robert demonstrated expertise through honest constraint advice.' Both recognize trust is foundational emotion. Existing focuses on friction reduction, new focuses on expertise demonstration.
reinforcements.recommendation: keep_both — Different trust mechanisms for different user states. Existing = baseline cognitive ease (reduce friction for all users). New = professional skepticism override (demonstrate expertise for sophisticated users like brokers). Both needed.

contradictions.new_element_id: works-002 (jessica run): Transparent Economics Before Commitment
contradictions.existing_element_id: behaves-002 (library: Sequential Disclosure: One Question at a Time)
contradictions.conflict: New element recommends showing ROI calculator + conversion benchmarks + comparative economics all at once during evaluation ('primary layer: ROI comparison, secondary: calculator, tertiary: conversion data'). Existing element advocates sequential disclosure: 'One question at a time, in the call's order. Never front-load complexity.'
contradictions.evidence_comparison: New (Jessica): 'Professional hosts evaluate through economic lens. Without transparent data upfront, they experience cognitive overload from mental math.' Existing (library): 'Sequential disclosure reduces cognitive load. Present information in call order, one step at a time.' NEW element has stronger evidence for professional host segment (Jessica explicitly spent 6+ minutes negotiating pricing because economics were unclear upfront), but existing element has broader applicability to general host population. Conflict is segment-specific.
contradictions.recommendation: Segment the pattern: Use progressive disclosure (existing pattern) for individual landlords, front-load economic transparency (new pattern) for professional hosts (brokers, property managers) who are accustomed to analyzing complex financial models. Add user segmentation logic to works-002: 'For professional hosts (brokers, agents), provide full economic transparency upfront. For individual landlords, use sequential disclosure.'

contradictions.conflict: New element recommends real-time pricing constraint feedback that appears as host drags slider toward problematic zones: 'This price is 20% above comparable properties. Reducing to $125/day would cut conversion time.' Existing element warns: 'Respect cognitive limits without patronizing. Never make the host feel corrected or second-guessed.'
contradictions.evidence_comparison: New (Jessica): 'Robert built trust by constraining Jessica's pricing: pricing things out of market would be no interest to anybody. Honest constraint advice built credibility.' Existing (library): 'The depleted host doesn't want to be told they're wrong. Frame guidance as support, not correction.' NEW element has strong Cialdini evidence (arguing against own interests builds trust) but existing element addresses user dignity concern. Conflict is in framing/tone, not substance.
contradictions.recommendation: Reconcile through collaborative framing: Keep constraint feedback (new pattern) but frame it collaboratively (existing principle). Use language like 'Based on what's converting right now, here's an adjustment that would help this listing perform better' vs. 'This price is wrong.' Constraint feedback should feel like expert coaching, not system criticism. Update communicates-003 to reference feels-007 and specify collaborative tone.

extensions.new_element_id: works-005 (jessica run): Communication Channel Preference Capture
extensions.gap_filled: Existing library has no elements addressing communication channel preference management (text vs. email routing based on host preference). This is a new pattern for managing professional hosts with email overload.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence with one lens. Jessica explicitly stated 'Text is preferred because you can imagine how many emails I get.' This reveals communication channel preference as a critical operational need for busy professional hosts. Pattern extends existing library by addressing notification routing based on host workflow constraints.

extensions.new_element_id: works-006 / communicates-006 / looks-006: Confidentiality Assurance / Trust Gate Documentation
extensions.gap_filled: Existing library has no elements addressing legal/contractual trust gates for B2B partnerships. Jessica demanded confidentiality agreement (08:42-09:05) because she operates in environment where legal agreements are standard trust mechanisms. Pattern extends library by addressing broker/agent partnership legal requirements.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence with one lens. Jessica's defensive demand for confidentiality agreement is strong evidence that B2B host segment (brokers, property managers) requires legal protection mechanisms that aren't present in current library. This is a structural need for professional hosts protecting client relationships.

extensions.new_element_id: looks-003 (jessica run): Honest Constraint Feedback Visual Pricing Guardrails
extensions.gap_filled: Existing library has visual patterns for trust (badges, typography, continuity) but no visual pattern for real-time constraint feedback during data input. Color-coded pricing zones (green/yellow/red) with constraint callout cards is new visual interaction pattern.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence with one lens. Robert's verbal constraint advice worked well with Jessica, and visual systematization (pricing slider with color zones) is logical extension. However, only one lens (professional broker) validates need. Would benefit from validation with individual landlords to confirm pattern applies broadly.

extensions.new_element_id: behaves-004 (jessica run): Scarcity Proof Progressive Evidence Accumulation
extensions.gap_filled: Existing library has elements for guaranteed income proof (feels-002) but no interaction pattern for progressively accumulating demand proof over time. Waitlist snapshot (24 hours) → engagement metrics (48 hours) → conversion velocity (7 days) is new temporal proof pattern.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence with one lens. Jessica's skeptical testing behavior ('I'll send a couple of listings by Friday') + Cialdini's 'newly experienced scarcity' principle create strong theoretical foundation. Pattern extends existing proof-based trust building (feels-002) by adding temporal dimension: proof must accumulate progressively to convert skepticism to belief.

extensions.new_element_id: feels-002 (jessica run): Economic Uncertainty to Confident Commitment
extensions.gap_filled: Existing library has feels-002 (Relief of Guaranteed Income) which addresses income security anxiety. New element addresses different anxiety: economic modeling uncertainty (Am I pricing correctly? Will I earn enough vs. traditional model?). Different emotional need.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence with one lens. Jessica spent 6+ minutes in economic uncertainty, challenging pricing expectations and asking for benchmarks. This anxiety is distinct from income guarantee anxiety (existing feels-002). New pattern addresses ROI modeling anxiety through interactive calculator + comparative benchmarks, filling gap in economic confidence journey.

extensions.new_element_id: feels-005 (jessica run): Communication Overload to Respected Efficiency
extensions.gap_filled: Existing library has no emotional elements addressing communication overload or channel preference respect. Jessica's 'Text is preferred because you can imagine how many emails I get' reveals emotional need: calm confidence that important messages will reach host through channels they monitor.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence with one lens. Jessica's explicit statement + professional context (busy broker, multiple deals, building visits) create strong evidence for communication anxiety. Pattern extends library by addressing professional host's time constraints and channel preferences as emotional trust factor.

new_tokens_flagged: slider-zone-green: #d4e8db (from looks-003, pricing slider green zone)
slider-zone-yellow: #fef8e7 (from looks-003, pricing slider yellow zone)
slider-zone-red: #fef0f0 (from looks-003, pricing slider red zone)
demand-active-bg: #e8f5ed (from looks-004, active guest search cards)
velocity-badge-bg: gradient from accent-light to surface-warm (from looks-004, conversion velocity)
channel-card-selected-border: 4px solid accent (from looks-005, channel card selection)
protection-card-border: 2px solid border (from looks-006, confidentiality cards)
token_compliance.recommendation: ADD new tokens to library. These tokens are semantically coherent extensions of existing color/spacing system. Most are lighter variants of existing accent/signal colors for specific UI states (hover, zones, selection). Gradient (velocity-badge-bg) is first gradient in system — review whether this aligns with 'not flashy' brand principle or if solid color alternative is better. Spacing token (timeline-event-spacing: 20px) fills gap between md (16px) and lg (24px) for specific timeline use case.

target_emotions: protected partnership (feels-003 new: control anxiety resolved)
collaborative trust (feels-001 new: through honest guidance)
validated enthusiasm (feels-004 new: skeptical testing → proof)
elements_contributing: works-004: Scarcity Validation Through Early Proof
communicates-006: Trust Gate Documentation (relationship protection panel)

target_emotions: validated enthusiasm (feels-004 new: demand proof sustained)
collaborative trust (feels-001 new: ongoing honest guidance)

arc_conflicts: Discovery to evaluation transition: Target emotion shifts from 'professional skepticism' to 'respect' — this requires authority demonstration + honest guidance. Current elements support this (works-001 credentials + works-003 honest constraints) but timing is critical. If host doesn't see authority credentials during discovery, they arrive at evaluation still skeptical, making transition harder. RECOMMENDATION: Ensure works-001 / communicates-001 / looks-001 are implemented in discovery touchpoints (partnership page, outreach messages) not just evaluation phase.

Evaluation to onboarding: Multiple anxieties (economic uncertainty, control anxiety, communication overload) must resolve simultaneously for host to commit. Risk: if any one anxiety persists (e.g., economics are clear but confidentiality isn't addressed), host won't proceed. RECOMMENDATION: Create evaluation 'pre-flight checklist' ensuring all three anxieties are addressed before requesting commitment: ✓ ROI calculator used, ✓ confidentiality assurance viewed, ✓ communication preference captured.

Listing creation emotional state: 'Confidence' requires both economic clarity (feels-002) AND honest guidance (feels-001). If host feels economically confident but receives no constraint feedback, they may overprice and later experience disappointment when listings don't convert. RECOMMENDATION: Ensure behaves-003 (constraint feedback) is non-optional — all hosts receive real-time pricing guidance, not just those who ask for it.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: Emotional arc for professional host journey (broker/agent segment) is coherent and evidence-based. Journey moves from defensive skepticism (discovery) → cautious respect (evaluation) → protected calm (onboarding) → confident execution (listing creation) → validated enthusiasm (proposal arrival). Each transition is supported by specific elements that address underlying anxieties. HOWEVER: This arc is specific to sophisticated professional hosts like Jessica. Individual landlords may have different emotional journey (e.g., less skepticism at discovery, more anxiety about operational complexity). RECOMMENDATION: Validate emotional arc with individual landlord lens to identify segment-specific variations.

discovery.gaps: Discovery elements focus on professional host authority checking. Missing: discovery patterns for individual landlords who may be motivated by different factors (financial need, property vacancy pressure). Missing: discovery elements for hosts who arrive via referral (different trust baseline than cold outreach).

evaluation.gaps: Evaluation is well-covered for economic, trust, and demand concerns. Missing: evaluation elements for hosts comparing Split Lease to competing platforms (not just traditional model). Missing: evaluation support for hosts with unusual property types or markets where benchmarks are thin.

onboarding.gaps: Onboarding elements address communication and confidentiality but missing: onboarding flow for hosts who need to get broker/supervisor approval (Jessica's 'I have to run it by my broker' gate). Missing: onboarding support for hosts managing multiple properties or entities.

listing_creation.gaps: Listing creation well-covered for pricing. Missing: listing creation elements for non-pricing attributes (photos, descriptions, amenities). Missing: listing creation support for hosts uploading multiple listings at once (batch operations).

elements: feels-002: Economic Uncertainty to Confident Commitment
pricing.gaps: Pricing is comprehensively covered. No major gaps identified.

elements: feels-004: Skeptical Testing to Validated Enthusiasm
proposal_mgmt.gaps: Proposal management well-covered for demand proof and notifications. Missing: proposal management elements for hosts choosing between multiple competing proposals (comparison tools, decision frameworks). Missing: proposal handling for hosts who are slow to respond (reminder strategies, urgency communication).

elements: communicates-006: Trust Gate (relationship protection panel visibility)
active_lease.gaps: Active lease is thinnest coverage phase. Missing: active lease elements for hosts managing ongoing guest relationships (issue resolution, payment tracking, lease renewals). Missing: active lease support for hosts with multiple concurrent leases (portfolio view, aggregate metrics).

retention.gaps: Retention is thinnest coverage phase. Missing: retention elements that convert successful one-time hosts into ongoing partners (portfolio expansion prompts, referral programs, partnership tier benefits). Missing: retention recovery patterns for hosts whose listings stop converting (re-engagement strategies, pricing optimization prompts).

loop_back_recommendations.reason: New element works-006 / communicates-006 (Confidentiality Assurance) reveals that legal/contractual trust gates are critical for B2B host segment (brokers, property managers). This pattern should be validated at Layer 1 (process) and Layer 2 (information architecture) with additional professional host calls to understand: What specific legal protections do brokers need? Are there jurisdictional variations? What about property managers vs. individual brokers?
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Interview 2-3 additional real estate brokers or property managers to validate confidentiality agreement requirements and relationship protection patterns. Specific questions: (1) What legal agreements do you typically require when partnering with platforms? (2) How do you protect your landlord relationships from being bypassed? (3) What visibility do you need into who accesses your client data?

loop_back_recommendations.reason: New element looks-003 / behaves-003 (Honest Constraint Feedback with visual pricing guardrails using color zones) introduces new visual interaction pattern (green/yellow/red zones on slider). This should be validated at Layer 3 (visual) and Layer 4 (interaction) with usability testing to ensure: (1) Color zones are perceived as helpful guidance, not patronizing correction. (2) Real-time constraint feedback doesn't create anxiety or friction. (3) Timing of guidance card appearance (at 80% threshold) feels anticipatory not intrusive.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Usability test pricing slider with color-coded zones with 5-10 hosts (mix of brokers and individual landlords). Observe: Do hosts notice zone colors? Do they adjust pricing in response to yellow/red warnings? Do they perceive constraint feedback as helpful or annoying? Measure: time to set price, final price accuracy (within recommended range), emotional response (confident vs. anxious).

loop_back_recommendations.reason: New element feels-004 (Skeptical Testing to Validated Enthusiasm) is based on Jessica's behavior of sending 'a couple of test listings' to validate demand claims. This emotional arc (skepticism → proof → enthusiasm) should be validated at Layer 5 with longitudinal tracking: Do hosts who start with test listings (cautious commitment) eventually scale to full portfolio (enthusiastic commitment) if proof arrives quickly? Or do test hosts remain cautious regardless of proof?
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Track cohort of 20-30 professional hosts who start with test listings (1-3 listings in first week). Measure: (1) Time to first proposal for test listings. (2) Host emotional response to first proposal (measured via follow-up interview or NPS survey). (3) Listing expansion behavior: do hosts who receive proposals within 7 days send more listings? (4) Retention: do test hosts who validate demand become long-term partners or one-time users?

loop_back_recommendations.reason: New elements reveal that professional hosts (brokers, agents) have fundamentally different process needs than individual landlords: (1) Broker approval gates (Jessica: 'I have to run it by my broker'), (2) Portfolio management (multiple properties, multiple entities), (3) Legal documentation requirements (confidentiality agreements), (4) Communication channel constraints (text vs. email due to overload). Layer 1 should re-examine whether professional host journey should be modeled as separate journey type (not just a segment of general host journey).
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Conduct 3-5 additional interviews with professional hosts (brokers, property managers, real estate agents) to map their end-to-end partnership journey. Focus on: (1) Decision-making process (who approves, what criteria, what timeline). (2) Portfolio management needs (how many properties, how often they onboard new inventory, batch operations). (3) Legal/compliance requirements specific to their professional role. (4) Success metrics (how do they evaluate partnership performance). Output: Separate 'Professional Host Journey Map' if differences are structural, not just preference-based.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: Contradiction identified between works-002 (front-load economic transparency for professional hosts) and existing behaves-002 (sequential disclosure for all hosts) suggests information architecture should adapt to user segment. Layer 2 should re-examine whether information hierarchy should be personalized based on host type: professional hosts get full transparency upfront (they can handle complexity), individual landlords get sequential disclosure (reduce cognitive overload).
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Design two variants of evaluation page information architecture: (1) Professional host variant: ROI calculator, conversion benchmarks, and comparative economics all visible above fold. (2) Individual landlord variant: Sequential disclosure with progressive complexity. A/B test with matched cohorts (50 professional hosts, 50 individual landlords per variant). Measure: time to commitment decision, comprehension (measured via post-evaluation quiz), confidence (measured via survey), commitment rate.
